basics.name: Andrea Siposova
basics.summary: Machine Learning researcher with 6+ years of experience, specializing in AI security and privacy-preserving machine learning. My experience includes designing and executing complex experiments, and deriving insights for improving model security and data confidentiality. Proven ability in project management and collaboration with cross-functional teams to advance research and development initiatives. Holding a Master’s degree in Data Science from Vienna University of Technology, with a thesis in the field of machine learning security.

work.name: <a href='https://www.sba-research.org'> SBA Research
highlights: Conducted systematic empirical studies to assess and enhance AI security and data confidentiality.
Designed experiments evaluating trade-oﬀs between attack and defense utility, model eﬀectiveness and robustness.
Developed 4 defense applications to integrate in a federated learning framework used across 3+ research projects.

Authored 6+ reports and articles detailing the methodologies, results, and implications in machine learning security and adversarial ML,supporting both internal knowledge sharing and external publications. Contributed to project proposals.
summary: <a href='https://www.sba-research.org/research/research-groups/mldm/'> Machine Learning and Data Management Group

work.name: <a href='https://www.sba-research.org'> SBA Research
highlights: Led a climate research project over 2.5 years focusing on landslide risk assessment.
Coordinated a multidisciplinary team of 15 experts resulting in solutions for landslide detection and susceptibility modeling.
Led a technical work package on data harmonization and model fusion, increased the change detection precision by 18%, efficiency by ~20%.
Contributed to the development of a data management workflow in the field of geo-sciences.
Organized a workshop on data management strategies to equip stakeholders in enhancing reproducibility, and data reliability.
Held focus groups to assess domain experts' needs and gather feedback for development.
summary: funded by <a href='https://www.kiras.at/en/home/'> The Austrian Security Research Program

work.name: <a href='https://tuwien.at/en'> TU Wien (Vienna University of Technology)
highlights: Conducted security assessments of federated learning systems to identify vulnerabilities and enhance data confidentiality.
Designed proof-of-concept of defenses to safeguard sensitive data in a federated learning environment.
Collaborated with partners in an international consortium consisting of 17 organizations from 11 countries.
summary: <a href='https://informatics.tuwien.ac.at/orgs/e194-04'> Research Unit Data Science, Institute Of Information Systems Engineering
<a href='https://defence-industry-space.ec.europa.eu/system/files/2023-06/NEWSROOM-Factsheet_EDF22.pdf'> European Defence Fund project focusing on Cyber Situational Awareness

work.name: <a href='https://tuwien.at/en'> TU Wien (Vienna University of Technology)
highlights: Developed and structured comprehensive machine learning assignments, actively collaborating with faculty members.
Conducted thorough assessment of over 500 student projects providing constructive feedback.

work.name: <a href='https://wu.ac.at/en'> WU Wien (Vienna University of Economics and Business)
highlights: Contributed to the development of object detection and image segmentation approaches.
Played a key role in project management, overseeing the project timeline, deliverables, and resource allocation.
Contributed to project reporting by ensuring accurate and timely documentation of research activities.
summary: <a href='https://www.wu.ac.at/en/firm'> Research Institute for Computational Methods

work.name: <a href='https://ondewo.com'> Ondewo)
highlights: Implemented advanced NLP techniques for a conversational chatbot, focusing on named entity recognition (NER) and intent detection.
Conducted data preprocessing and feature engineering to enhance the performance of deep learning models for NLP tasks.
Performed an analysis of model outcomes and documented the development process and findings.

education.institution: <a href='https://www.tuwien.at/en/'> TU Wien (Vienna University of Technology)
courses: <a href='https://doi.org/10.34726/hss.2023.92803'> Diploma Thesis: Data Exfiltration Attacks and Defenses in Neural Networks:
Simulated data exfiltration attacks on neural networks through intentional memorization in white-box and black-box scenarios.
Conducted in-depth evaluation of attack effectiveness regarding various attack hyperparameters and evaluated attack vs. defense vs. model utility trade-oﬀs.
Designed and applied defense mechanisms, enhancing neural network security and robustness against exfiltration threats.
Introduced a taxonomy of data exfiltration attacks in machine learning.
Thesis & Defensio grade: 100%, Coursework grade average: 89%

education.institution: <a href='https://www.wu.ac.at/en/'> WU Wien (Vienna University of Economics and Business)

publications.name: Zur Elektrody/namik bewegter Körper
publications.summary: It concerned an interpretation of the Michelson–Morley experiment and the properties of light and time. Special relativity incorporates the principle that the speed of light is the same for all inertial observers regardless of the state of motion of the source.

publications.name: Über einen die Erzeugung und Verwandlung des Lichtes betreffenden heuristischen Gesichtspunkt
publications.summary: In the second paper, he applied the quantum theory to light to explain the photoelectric effect. In particular, he used the idea of light quanta (photons) to explain experimental results, but stressed the importance of the experimental results. The importance of his work on the photoelectric effect earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.

publications.name: Die Grundlage der allgemeinen Relativitätstheorie
publications.summary: The publication of the theory of general relativity made him internationally famous. He was professor of physics at the universities of Zurich (1909–1911) and Prague (1911–1912), before he returned to ETH Zurich (1912–1914).

projects.name: Quantum Computing
projects.summary: Quantum computing is the use of quantum-mechanical phenomena such as superposition and entanglement to perform computation. Computers that perform quantum computations are known as quantum computers.
highlights: Quantum Teleportation
Quantum Cryptography
